title: Dementia patient is charged after allegedly ringing police 500 times
text:
A dementia patient has been charged after he allegedly called the police 500 times in just one day.

Van Tran, from Sydney, in NSW, claims he doesn't remember making any of the calls.

But New South Wales police have defended charging the 60-year-old, saying they won't allow people to 'tie up' their services.

Speaking with A Current Affair, Mr Tran denied phoning the police.

'I'm a good person. 'I no call them,' Mr Tran told A Current Affair.

But authorities said they won't 'tolerate' his behaviour.

'Police will not tolerate people who call and tie up our services,' a spokesperson for NSW Police said.

Van Tran (pictured) has been charged over allegedly calling the police 500 times in just one day

Mr Tran's carer, Stephen Bennett, lashed out at the charges, saying they were 'absolutely absurd'.

'He's the most non-violent, peaceful person I have ever met,' Mr Bennett said.

Currently there are more than 400,000 people battling with dementia in Australia.

The illness is the second leading cause of death within the country and the highest cause of death for women.

Mr Tran's full story will air on A Current Affair on Nine on Thursday night.

Daily Mail Australia has contacted NSW Police for comment.
description: Sydney man, Van Tran, claims he doesn't remember making any of the 500 calls he allegedly made to police.
authors: Eliza Mcphee For Daily Mail Australia
